Alcohol experts from Sheffield University have studied the health picture, drinks market and consumption patterns in Wales.

The research has helped produce a formula based on the percentage strength of the alcohol and its volume to develop the minimum unit price (MUP).

While alcohol consumption levels have been falling in recent years, health officials are concerned that:

Cheap drink in supermarkets and other licensed stores is the main target and the law will also address the issue of special offers in its fine detail.

Alcohol sold below 50p per unit makes up 72% of the beer sales in Welsh shops and supermarkets, 78% of the cider sales, 42% of the wine and 66% of the spirits.

The research suggests that although high-risk drinkers make up only a quarter of people who drink alcohol, they drink 72% of all alcohol consumed and account for 65% of all spending.

"There is a very clear and direct link between levels of excessive drinking and the availability of cheap alcohol," said Public Health Minister Rebecca Evans.

"So we need to take decisive action now to address the affordability of alcohol, as part of wider efforts to tackle alcohol-related harm."

It has been claimed it could:

Chief Medical Officer Dr Frank Atherton said they were not the "fun police" or the "nanny state" but they could not wash their hands of a significant public health issue.

"It will have a small impact on moderate drinkers," he added.

"The most substantial effects will be experienced by harmful and hazardous drinkers, who are more likely to consume cheaper and higher-strength alcohol products."

But Alex Loveland, a recovering alcoholic who supports people with dependency, is worried that it will not help them.

"They're going to try to get alcohol by any means necessary and I think it will put more strain on very underprivileged people," he said.

The Welsh Retail Consortium has also expressed concern that minimum price may hit less affluent, moderate consumers of alcohol "whilst not necessarily having the desired impact on problem drinkers".

UKIP Wales leader Neil Hamilton AM said it was another example of the Welsh Government "sticking its nose into people's private lives".

"The problem is not alcohol but anti-social behaviour," he said. "The laws on public drunkenness need to be strictly enforced, as they used to be."

But Prof Mark Bellis, director of policy at Public Health Wales, said it would reduce opportunities for young people to buy alcohol "at pocket money prices".

Dr David Bailey, chair of the BMA's Welsh Council said it was behind measures "to ensure that alcohol cannot be sold below cost - in effect, making it cheaper than water to purchase".

Addictions charity Cais said although the law would not solve alcohol problems on its own it was an "important day for Wales" and stressed that it would save lives.

This video can not be played To play this video you need to enable JavaScript in your browser. Rebecca Evans emphasised that it was not a tax but would be tackle problem drinking

The legislation is back on the table five years after the Welsh Government first looked at introducing it.

The measure had been removed from the most recent Welsh public health law as Scotland faced court challenges to its own legislation.

The Supreme Court is expected to give its judgement within weeks to an attempt to block Scotland's minimum price legislation from being introduced.

Ms Evans told BBC Radio Wales that the Welsh Government had moved "quickly" to introduce its own legislation because the powers to do so will be removed next April under the terms of the 2017 Wales Act.

"If we are going to act on this area it has to be now, even though we realise that there's a difficult legal context that we are working in," she said.

Ministers in Wales hope it will become law by summer 2018.

Councils would enforce the legislation through their existing inspection and trading standards regime - with powers of entry, prosecution and the issue of fixed penalty notices.

Talks have been held with local government about funding towards its initial introduction.

原始信息翻译:
威尔士公布了一项设定酒精最低售价的法律草案。

政府部长们相信，解决过度饮酒问题每周可以挽救一条生命，并每年减少1,400次住院。

定价被视为公共健康努力中的一个“缺失环节”，与提高意识和治疗措施相辅相成。

根据每单位酒精50便士的公式，普通罐装苹果酒至少要卖1英镑，而一瓶葡萄酒至少要卖4.69英镑。

例如，普通升装伏特加的价格必须超过20英镑。

不过，威尔士政府尚未决定具体的价格。

谢菲尔德大学的酒精专家研究了威尔士的健康状况、酒类市场和消费模式。

研究帮助制定了一个基于酒精浓度和体积的公式，以确定最低单位价格（MUP）。

尽管近年来酒精消费水平有所下降，卫生官员仍然担心：

超市和其他持牌商店中的廉价酒饮是主要目标，法律也将在细节上解决特价促销的问题。

每单位低于50便士的酒精产品占威尔士商店和超市啤酒销售的72%、苹果酒销售的78%、葡萄酒销售的42%和烈酒销售的66%。

研究表明，尽管高风险饮酒者仅占饮酒者的四分之一，他们却消耗了72%的酒精，并占据了65%的酒精花费。

“过度饮酒水平与廉价酒精的可得性之间有非常明确且直接的联系，”公共健康部长丽贝卡·埃文斯说道。

“因此，我们需要现在采取果断行动，解决酒精的可负担性问题，作为解决酒精相关危害的更广泛努力的一部分。”

有人声称这可能：

首席医疗官弗兰克·阿瑟顿博士表示，他们不是“乐趣警察”或“保姆国家”，但他们不能对重大的公共健康问题袖手旁观。

“这对适度饮酒者影响很小，”他补充道。

“最显著的影响将体现在有害和危险的饮酒者身上，他们更可能消费廉价和高浓度的酒精产品。”

但支持依赖症患者的戒酒者亚历克斯·洛夫兰德担心这对他们没有帮助。

“他们会想尽一切办法获取酒精，我认为这将给非常贫困的人群带来更大压力，”他说。

威尔士零售联盟也表达了担忧，认为最低价格可能会影响到不太富裕的适度酒精消费者，“而不一定对问题饮酒者产生预期影响”。

英国独立党威尔士领导人尼尔·汉密尔顿议员表示，这是威尔士政府“干涉人们私人生活”的又一个例子。

“问题不在于酒精，而在于反社会行为，”他说。“公众醉酒的法律需要像以前那样严格执行。”

但公共健康威尔士政策主任马克·贝里斯教授表示，这将减少年轻人以“零花钱价格”购买酒精的机会。

英国医学会威尔士委员会主席大卫·贝利博士表示，他们支持“确保酒精不能低于成本价出售——实际上使其比水更便宜”的措施。

成瘾慈善机构Cais表示，尽管法律本身不能解决酒精问题，但这是威尔士的“重要一天”，并强调这将拯救生命。

该立法是在威尔士政府首次考虑引入它五年后重回议程。

这一措施曾从最近的威尔士公共健康法中移除，因为苏格兰面临其立法的法律挑战。

最高法院预计将在几周内对阻止苏格兰最低价格立法的诉讼作出判决。

埃文斯女士告诉BBC威尔士电台，威尔士政府迅速采取行动引入自己的立法，因为根据2017年威尔士法案的条款，该权力将在明年四月被取消。

“如果我们要在这个领域采取行动，就必须是现在，尽管我们意识到我们面临的法律环境非常复杂，”她说。

威尔士的部长们希望这项法律能在2018年夏天前生效。

地方政府将通过现有的检查和交易标准制度来执行该立法——并拥有进入、起诉和发出固定罚款通知的权力。

关于初步引入的资金问题，已与地方政府进行了会谈。

原始正确信息:
Boris Johnson has insisted he is "all behind" Theresa May after setting out his own vision of Britain after Brexit.

Writing in the Daily Telegraph, the foreign secretary revived the contested claim Brexit could free up £350m a week for the NHS and also said the UK should not pay for EU single market access.

He later tweeted he backed the PM, who is making a major EU speech next week.

Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable said the £350m figure was "a lie" while Jeremy Corbyn said it showed Tory divisions.

In a 4,000 word piece for the newspaper, Mr Johnson expanded at length on his views about the Brexit negotiations with the EU, and the opportunities he said it would give a "bold, thriving" Britain when it leaves in March 2019.

If Britain did continue its membership of the single market and customs union it would make a "complete mockery" of last year's referendum result, he wrote.

The UK, he argued, would be "roughly" £350m better off once it had "settled its accounts" with the EU and he said it would be "fine" if "a lot of that money" was spent on the health service.

Writing later on Twitter, Mr Johnson said that he was "looking forward" to the prime minister's speech next Friday in Florence - in which she is expected to set out details of the UK's "special partnership" with the EU after Brexit.

"All behind Theresa for a glorious Brexit," he wrote.

The BBC's political correspondent Leila Nathoo said that although sources close to Mr Johnson insist his article has nothing to do with leadership ambitions, the intervention has revived speculation that he is still eyeing the top job.

Asked for her response, Home Secretary Amber Rudd said she was focused on co-ordinating the government's response to the Parsons Green bomb attack and had hadn't a chance to look at the article.

But Sir Vince Cable suggested the foreign secretary was pushing for "a far more extreme" version of Brexit in pursuit of his own personal ambitions.

"On his central point, the £350m a week, this is a lie. He knows it is a lie and endlessly repeating it does not make it the truth," he said.

And the Lib Dems Brexit spokesman Tom Brake told his party conference - which began on Saturday - that far from enhancing the NHS, the UK's exit would have a "calamitous effect on our cherished public services".

Chancellor Philip Hammond has suggested there is a consensus in the cabinet for the need for a transitional period of several years to minimise the disruption from Brexit - which would "look a lot like the status quo" in many ways.

This has prompted unconfirmed speculation that the UK could potentially pay the EU for a limited period of time to continue to access the single market on an existing tariff-free basis.

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said Mr Johnson's comments "laid bare the conflicts at the heart of Theresa May's government over Brexit" and undermined the prime minister's authority.

He said: "The foreign secretary even has the gall to dredge up the fantasy of £350m a week extra for the NHS.

"The prime minister must spell out now how this will be paid for, or stand condemned for once again trying to mislead the British public."

In the run up to the referendum, the Leave campaign - of which Mr Johnson was a key figure - claimed the UK sent £20bn a year, or £350m a week, to Brussels in 2014.

Vote Leave emblazoned the figure on its campaign bus and said the money could be used to fund extra spending on public services such as the NHS.

鲍里斯·约翰逊坚称他“完全支持”特蕾莎·梅，同时提出了自己关于脱欧后英国的愿景。

在《每日电讯报》上撰文时，这位外交大臣重提了备受争议的说法，即脱欧后每周可以为NHS（国民健康服务）释放3.5亿英镑的资金，并表示英国不应为进入欧盟单一市场支付费用。

随后，他在推特上表示支持首相梅，后者将在下周发表重大欧盟演讲。

自由民主党领袖文斯·凯布尔爵士称这3.5亿英镑的数字是“谎言”，而杰里米·科尔宾则表示这显示出保守党内部的分歧。

在为报纸撰写的一篇4000字文章中，约翰逊先生详细阐述了他对与欧盟进行的脱欧谈判的看法，以及他所说的2019年3月英国离开后将成为“大胆、繁荣”的国家所面临的机遇。

他写道，如果英国继续保持单一市场和关税同盟的成员身份，将完全背离去年的公投结果。

约翰逊认为，一旦与欧盟“结清账目”，英国将“约有”3.5亿英镑的盈余，他表示如果将“大部分资金”用于医疗服务将是“不错的”。

随后在推特上，约翰逊先生表示他“期待”首相下周五在佛罗伦萨的演讲——预计她将在演讲中详述英国脱欧后的“特殊伙伴关系”。

“全力支持特蕾莎，为辉煌的脱欧，”他写道。

BBC政治记者莱拉·纳图表示，尽管约翰逊身边的人坚称他的文章与领导意图无关，但这一干预已引发他仍在觊觎最高职位的猜测。

当被问及她的回应时，内政大臣安珀·拉德表示她正专注于协调政府对帕森斯格林爆炸案的响应，还没有机会查看这篇文章。

但文斯·凯布尔爵士则暗示，外交大臣正推动一种“更为极端”的脱欧版本，以追求个人野心。

“关于他强调的核心问题，即每周3.5亿英镑，这是谎言。他知道这是谎言，不断重复并不能使其成为事实，”他说。

自由民主党脱欧发言人汤姆·布雷克在其党代会上表示，英国的退出不仅不会加强NHS，还会对我们珍视的公共服务产生“灾难性影响”。

财政大臣菲利普·哈蒙德建议内阁已达成共识，认为需要几年的过渡期以尽量减少脱欧带来的干扰——这在许多方面将“非常像现状”。

这引发了未经证实的猜测，英国可能在有限时间内向欧盟支付费用，以继续以现有的免关税基础进入单一市场。

工党领袖杰里米·科尔宾表示，约翰逊的言论“揭示了特蕾莎·梅政府在脱欧问题上的核心冲突”，并削弱了首相的权威。

他说：“外交大臣甚至厚颜无耻地重提每周额外3.5亿英镑用于NHS的幻想。”

“首相必须立即明确说明如何支付这笔费用，否则将因再次试图误导英国公众而受到谴责。”

在公投前，约翰逊是“离开”阵营的关键人物，该阵营声称英国在2014年每年向布鲁塞尔支付200亿英镑，即每周3.5亿英镑。

“投票离开”在其竞选巴士上印上了这个数字，并表示这笔钱可以用于增加对公共服务的支出，例如NHS。

但英国统计监督机构负责人安德鲁·迪尔诺爵士在公投期间的一封信中称这一数字“可能具有误导性”。

3.5亿英镑的数字是“离开”阵营的主要宣传信息之一。

英国每周向欧盟支付3.5亿英镑的说法是不正确的。

有三个因素需要考虑：

鲍里斯·约翰逊和其他“离开”阵营的支持者声称在2014年，英国每周向欧盟支付3.5亿英镑。

英国的总贡献实际上是3.61亿英镑，但在任何资金汇给欧盟之前，重要的是要扣除回扣。因此，2014年向欧盟支付的金额为每周2.76亿英镑，扣除回扣后。

“投票离开”阵营声称这笔钱可以用于NHS。

的确可以，但那意味着削减欧盟返还给英国的所有资金，例如农业补贴和社区项目的拨款。

那是在2014年。英国向欧盟支付的金额一直在减少。2016年，在扣除回扣后，英国每周向欧盟支付2.52亿英镑，是自2012年以来的最低水平。

Twenty firefighters remained at the scene on Monday afternoon, damping down the building.

几十人从酒店和周边建筑撤离

在一场大火吞噬了迪赛德一家酒店后，调查已经开始，近50人被迫撤离。

火灾摧毁了位于弗林特郡昆斯费里附近的威尔士大道上的Gateway to Wales酒店的一楼、屋顶及大部分底层。

火警于格林威治标准时间凌晨4:30响起，60名消防员在中午12:00前扑灭了火灾。没有人在火灾中受伤。

由于烟雾弥漫，道路和附近的一所学校被关闭。

北威尔士消防部门表示，所有47名客人和一名工作人员都已确认安全。

消防部门的高级运营经理斯图尔特·米灵顿表示，酒店的烟雾警报响起后，所有人都安全撤离。

他说：“我们的火灾调查人员正在与当地居民和建筑物内的人们交谈。”

“建筑物损坏严重，因此他们进入进行安全调查将需要一些时间。”

周一下午，现场仍有20名消防员对建筑物进行降温处理。

住在酒店旁边公寓楼里的丹尼·劳顿和他的女友以及他们的宝宝说他被警察敲门叫醒是在凌晨5点。

In an innovative campaign Mr Mélenchon addressed Parisians from a barge

Is it the mellowing of age? Is it a return to an original kinder self? Or is it all part of a brilliant pre-election re-make?

No-one knows the answer, but everyone understands the question. Something has changed in Jean-Luc Mélenchon.

At the last election in 2012 he was the far-left candidate who ate quote-hunting journalists for breakfast. He fulminated and he fumed. Supporters loved him, but most of the population took fright.

This time around France's scourge of capitalism is as sharp as ever with his tongue. But gone is the hate and the wall-to-wall vituperation. Instead, he plays on another rhetorical chord, which is humour.

The snarl has been replaced by the smile, and the Mélenchon ratings have gone through the ceiling.

For his critics this is disconcerting, because behind the new-found charm they see the same irresponsible firebrand as first stormed out of the Socialist Party (PS) nearly a decade ago.

Born in Tangiers in 1951 of Spanish-Italian extraction, Jean-Luc Mélenchon had a career in teaching and journalism before launching himself into Socialist politics in the late 1970s.

Gravitating to the left of the party, he served briefly as junior education minister under Prime Minister Lionel Jospin. In 2002 he co-founded a movement, Nouveau Monde (New World), which attacked what it saw as the Socialist party's rightward drift.

Jean-Luc Mélenchon chose the distinctive Greek letter phi as his movement's logo

He voted against the EU's proposed constitution in 2005, on the grounds that it would turn market capitalism into a permanent state of being. Three years later he decided the Socialists had become a party of sell-outs, and left for good.

After setting up a new Parti de Gauche (Left Party), he was elected as a Euro MP in 2009 in an alliance with the Communists.

Now he is once again backed by the Communists in this, his second presidential campaign. But he eschews traditional party affiliations. Instead, his movement is called La France Insoumise (France unbowed), and its symbol is the Greek letter phi (from the initials of the movement).

More on the French election:

Jean-Luc Mélenchon's programme has changed little from 2012. He wants the presidential system of the Fifth Republic to be replaced by a government more directly answerable to parliament.

He wants a €100bn (£84bn; $107bn) state investment plan; a top tax rate of 90%; retirement at 60; a 32-hour working week; 200,000 new state-paid jobs; and a ban on firing workers when companies are making profits.

He wants to renegotiate the EU treaties so that the European Central Bank answers to political, rather than purely monetary, interests; and an end to so-called "austerity" rules that put limits on national deficits.

He would leave Nato and the IMF, and even bring France (via its territory of Guyane) into the little-known Latin American union Alba (Bolivarian Alliance for the Americas), which was set up by Cuba's Fidel Castro and Venezuela's Hugo Chavez.

Mr Mélenchon (R) wears a worker's jacket with a red triangle on the collar, a symbol worn by communists deported by the Nazis in World War Two

Jean-Luc Mélenchon's manifesto is immediately recognisable. But this time the sales pitch is different.

The old iconography has disappeared. The red flags no longer fly at rallies, and he has ditched the singing of the Internationale. He refuses to be described as far-left, and does not even mind the term populist.

His communications team has been masterly.

In popular YouTube videos he speaks directly to voters, defying the quick-click culture with detailed lectures on economics.

His smartness of phrase was a hit in the presidential debates. The jibe, not the insult, is now his strength.

But the pièces de résistance, certainly from the PR viewpoint, have been the hologram rallies, in which he has appeared simultaneously in venues hundreds of kilometres apart, striding the stage in his old-fashioned teacher's jacket and expounding on the evils of the system.

Some critics argue the whole Mélenchon campaign contains an element of the hologram: his proposals are insubstantial because they are totally unrealistic.

The skill has been in the communication, in articulating and spreading a message that many people, clearly, are very happy to hear.

The relief in Brussels is palpable. It believes it is (almost) back from the brink.

A passionate Europhile, Emmanuel Macron's presidential campaign is as much blue and yellow as it is the "tricolour" of France.

The EU, he believes, should to be at the heart of French politics, with more integration in finance, defence and migration.

He wants to breathe life into the now-spluttering Franco-German motor; to take a lead role with Germany to - in his eyes - Make Europe Great Again.

Angela Merkel and the European Commission's Jean-Claude Juncker can hardly conceal their delight. Both were quick to get on the phone to congratulate Mr Macron on his strong showing in Sunday's vote.

By this autumn fervent Eurocrats hope to look back fondly to a string of electoral defeats for populist Eurosceptics in Austria, the Netherlands, France, and then Germany.

But they shouldn't count their chickens.

Euroscepticism is widespread in France, whether or not Marine Le Pen becomes president.

In the post-industrial north-east of France, with its hopelessly high unemployment, and in the resentful south-east with its struggling small businesses, globalisation and the EU are seen as joint public enemy number one.

The nostalgic nationalism peddled by Ms Le Pen is a source of comfort and hope.

"In the name of the people" is her campaign slogan. Woman of the people is her image.

She was the only presidential candidate amongst 11 to hold their Sunday night election party outside Paris, basing herself in the troubled town of Hénin-Beaumont where she first made a political name for herself as a local councillor.

Sharpening her political claws against Emmanuel Macron, she is now keen to portray him as an arrogant elite-educated former banker, best friend of Brussels and the French bourgeoisie.

And if Ms Le Pen beats the odds and garners France's top political job, that would spell the end of the European project as we know it.

She wants France out of the euro - which so many French blame for high prices and uncompetitiveness.

And she dreams of the EU's demise, favouring a looser union of European nations over what she calls Brussels-domination.

The two will now go head-to-head in the second round

Post-Brexit Britain would then be high up on her list of preferred European partners.

But before that could happen, current Brexit negotiations and future trade talks would be left hanging as the EU slowly imploded.

There would be chaos across EU countries which would affect Britain too.

A President Macron, when it comes to Brexit, would likely play hardball.

He would help to keep the EU united in negotiations, making it harder for the UK to pick off individual countries, attempting to pressure or entice them to make a sweeter Brexit deal.

But EU passion aside, Mr Macron is not wedded to ideology. He is a newcomer to politics who claims to be neither right- nor left-wing.

During his meeting with Theresa May in February he said post-Brexit economic, defence and security co-operation with Britain must remain close.

As a former (if not long-standing) Minister of the Economy in France, he is unlikely to turn up his nose at a good trade deal with the UK.

作为热情的欧洲拥护者，埃马纽埃尔·马克龙的总统竞选活动不仅是法国的“三色旗”，也是蓝色和黄色的象征。

他认为，欧盟应该成为法国政治的核心，推动在金融、防务和移民领域的更多融合。

他希望重振现已步履蹒跚的法德合作引擎，与德国共同承担领导角色，在他看来，这是在“让欧洲再次伟大”。

安吉拉·默克尔和欧盟委员会的让-克洛德·容克几乎难掩他们的喜悦。两人迅速打电话祝贺马克龙在周日选举中表现强劲。

到今年秋天，热情的欧盟官员希望能怀念一系列在奥地利、荷兰、法国，随后在德国中，民粹主义欧盟怀疑论者的选举失败。

但他们不应该过早乐观。

欧盟怀疑论在法国普遍存在，无论玛丽娜·勒庞是否当选总统。

在法国的后工业化东北部地区，失业率高得令人绝望；在心怀不满的东南部地区，小企业举步维艰，全球化和欧盟被视为公敌。

勒庞宣扬的怀旧民族主义成为一种慰藉和希望。

“以人民的名义”是她的竞选口号。她的形象是人民的女性代表。

她是11位总统候选人中唯一一个在周日晚上将选举派对设在巴黎之外的人，她将总部设在赫宁-博蒙，这个困扰重重的城镇，她首次在此作为地方议员崭露头角。

她正在磨砺政治利爪，试图将马克龙描绘成傲慢的精英教育背景的前银行家，是布鲁塞尔和法国资产阶级的好朋友。

如果勒庞逆袭赢得法国最高政治职位，那将意味着我们所知的欧洲项目的终结。

她希望法国退出欧元——许多法国人归咎于它导致物价高涨和竞争力下降。

她梦想欧盟解体，倾向于松散的欧洲国家联盟，而不是她所谓的布鲁塞尔主导。

两人将在第二轮中正面对决。

脱欧后的英国将成为她优先考虑的欧洲伙伴之一。

但在那发生之前，当前的脱欧谈判和未来的贸易谈判将被搁置，因为欧盟逐渐崩溃。

这将导致整个欧盟国家的混乱，也会影响到英国。

而如果马克龙当选总统，在脱欧问题上，他可能会采取强硬态度。

他会帮助保持欧盟在谈判中的团结，使英国更难以逐个击破国家，试图施压或诱使他们达成更有利的脱欧协议。

但撇开对欧盟的热情不谈，马克龙并不执着于意识形态。他是政治新手，自称既不偏左也不偏右。

在他与特蕾莎·梅二月份的会面中，他表示脱欧后的经济、防务和安全合作必须与英国保持紧密关系。

作为法国前（虽不是长期担任的）经济部长，他不太可能拒绝与英国达成良好的贸易协议。

Prince Charles paid tribute to his "very special godmother"

Prince Philip's cousin, the Countess Mountbatten of Burma, has died aged 93.

Patricia Mountbatten married celebrated film producer Lord Brabourne in 1946, and the pair had seven children.

The couple were among a seven-strong boat party blown up by the IRA at County Sligo, Republic of Ireland, in 1979.

Their son Nicholas, 14, was killed in the attack, as was Lord Brabourne's mother, Dowager Lady Brabourne, and her father Lord Mountbatten.

The Countess, then known as Lady Brabourne, was badly injured but her husband survived as did Nicholas's twin, Timothy.

For more than 30 years she used her experience of her loss to help other bereaved parents, through her support of the charities Child Bereavement UK and Compassionate Friends.

A spokeswoman for the family said the countess died peacefully on Tuesday at her home in Mersham, Kent, surrounded by her children.

She was godmother to the Prince of Wales who paid tribute to her in a statement. It reads: "I was deeply saddened to learn of the death of my very special godmother, Lady Mountbatten, whom I have known and loved ever since I can first remember.

"She played an extremely important part in my life and I shall miss her presence most dreadfully."

A Buckingham Palace spokeswoman said: "The Queen and the Duke are aware and have privately passed on their condolences."

When the Countess married in 1946 the then Princess Elizabeth, her third cousin, was one of her bridesmaids.

The family lived at Broadlands in Romsey, Hampshire, near Southampton, which has a hospice named after Countess Mountbatten.

The arrangements for a funeral in London followed by a burial service in Mersham, are to be announced at a later date.

菲利普亲王的表亲、缅甸蒙巴顿伯爵夫人去世，享年93岁。

帕特里夏·蒙巴顿于1946年与著名电影制片人布拉伯恩勋爵结婚，两人育有七个孩子。

这对夫妇是1979年在爱尔兰共和国斯莱戈郡被爱尔兰共和军炸毁的七人划船派对中的一员。

他们14岁的儿子尼古拉斯在袭击中遇难，还有布拉伯恩勋爵的母亲布拉伯恩夫人，以及她的父亲蒙巴顿勋爵。

伯爵夫人当时被称为布拉伯恩夫人，伤势严重，但她的丈夫幸存下来，尼古拉斯的双胞胎蒂莫西也活了下来。

三十多年来，她利用自己失去亲人的经历，通过支持慈善机构“英国儿童丧亲关怀”和“慈爱朋友”，帮助其他失去子女的父母。

一位家族发言人表示，伯爵夫人周二在肯特郡梅尔沙姆的家中安详去世，身边围绕着她的孩子们。

伯爵夫人于1946年结婚时，当时的伊丽莎白公主，她的三表亲，是她的伴娘之一。

家族住在汉普郡罗姆西的布罗德兰庄园，靠近南安普顿，该地有一家以蒙巴顿伯爵夫人命名的临终关怀医院。

葬礼安排将在伦敦举行，随后在梅尔沙姆进行安葬仪式，具体日期将稍后公布。

他们14岁的儿子尼古拉斯在谈判中发挥了关键作用，与布拉博恩勋爵的母亲——布拉博恩夫人——和她的父亲蒙巴顿勋爵一同努力。

当时被称为布拉博恩夫人的伯爵夫人在和平谈判中发挥了重要作用，她的丈夫和尼古拉斯的双胞胎兄弟蒂莫西也继续支持她。

三十多年来，她利用自己的经验，通过支持联合国和“直接和平”等组织来推动全球和平。

诺贝尔委员会的一位女发言人表示，伯爵夫人因其毕生致力于和平以及在冲突解决方面的开创性努力而获得该奖项。

查尔斯王子在声明中称赞了她的成就：“我深感荣幸地见证了我那非常特别的教母蒙巴顿夫人获得认可，我自童年起就一直钦佩她在和平方面的非凡贡献。”

白金汉宫的一位女发言人表示：“女王和公爵对她的成就感到无比自豪，并已私下向她表示祝贺。”

1946年伯爵夫人结婚时，当时的伊丽莎白公主，她的第三代堂妹，是她的伴娘之一。

这家人住在汉普郡罗姆西的布罗德兰斯，靠近南安普顿，那里举办以蒙巴顿伯爵夫人命名的国际和平峰会。

伦敦的庆祝活动安排以及随后在马沙姆的仪式聚会的细节将在以后宣布。

BBC承认伯爵夫人的工作具有全球影响力。

A Google employee's opinion criticising the firm's diversity initiatives is causing a furore at the firm.

In an internal memo, a male software engineer argued the lack of women in top tech jobs was due to biological differences between men and women.

"We need to stop assuming that gender gaps imply sexism," he wrote in the piece which was widely criticised.

But the author said he had received "many personal messages from fellow Googlers expressing their gratitude".

Posted on an internal discussion board, the article was published in full by tech website Gizmodo.

Former Reddit boss Ellen Pao was among a number of women from the tech industry to criticise the memo

It argues that the "abilities of men and women differ in part due to biological causes and that these differences may explain why we don't see equal representation of women in tech and leadership".

The unnamed author says women generally "prefer jobs in social or artistic areas" while "more men may like coding".

The article prompted a response from the search engine giant's new head of diversity Danielle Brown, who said "the heated debate" over the issue had "compelled" her to say a few words.

In an internal email, published by tech website Motherboard, she said the article was "not a viewpoint that I or this company endorses, promotes or encourages".

谷歌一名员工发表的意见批评该公司多元化举措，引发了公司内的轩然大波。

在一份内部备忘录中，一名男性软件工程师声称，顶级科技职位中女性缺乏的原因是男女之间的生物差异。

“我们需要停止假设性别差距意味着性别歧视，”他在这篇广受批评的文章中写道。

但作者表示，他收到了“许多来自谷歌同事的个人信息，表达他们的感激之情”。

这篇文章发布在内部讨论板上，并由科技网站Gizmodo全文刊登。

前Reddit负责人艾伦·帕奥是批评该备忘录的多位科技行业女性之一。

她认为，“男女能力的差异部分是由于生物原因，这些差异可能解释了为什么女性在科技和领导职位上的代表性不均衡。”

文章的匿名作者称女性通常“更倾向于社交或艺术领域的工作”，而“更多男性可能喜欢编码”。

这篇文章引发了搜索引擎巨头谷歌的新任多元化主管丹妮尔·布朗的回应，她表示“围绕这一问题的激烈辩论”促使她发表一些看法。

在一封内部电子邮件中，她表示，科技网站Motherboard发表的文章“不是我或本公司认可、支持或鼓励的观点”。

“多元化和包容是我们价值观的基本组成部分，也是我们不断培养的文化的一部分，”她补充道。

“我们坚信多元化和包容对于我们公司的成功至关重要，我们将继续为此奋斗，并长期致力于此。”

在社交媒体上，女性纷纷发声批评备忘录以及工作场所中更普遍的性别歧视态度。

在Medium网站的博客中，前谷歌工程师埃里卡·贝克表示，她“失望但并不感到意外”。

“这不是完全新的行为……新的只是这名员工感到足够安全，可以在内部写下并分享一篇八页的性别歧视文章，”她写道。

谷歌在六月发布的多元化报告显示，其总员工中约69%是男性，56%是白人。

女性仅占领导角色的25%和技术岗位（如电脑程序员）的20%。

关于科技行业更广泛的性别歧视和缺乏多元化的文化的投诉一直存在。

包括首席执行官特拉维斯·卡兰尼克在内的几名高管今年辞职，原因是共享乘车公司优步未能妥善处理关于性骚扰的投诉。

而硅谷投资者贾斯汀·卡尔德贝克在六月被指控性骚扰六名女性科技高管后，选择无限期休假。

“男性风险投资家与女性创业者之间的影响力差距令人恐惧，我讨厌我的行为在营造性别敌对环境方面起到了作用，”卡尔德贝克先生在当时发布的声明中写道。

原始正确信息:
Amal Clooney has given birth to twins - a girl named Ella and a boy named Alexander.

They were born in London on Tuesday morning, the publicist of her actor husband George Clooney said.

"Ella, Alexander and Amal are all healthy, happy and doing fine," Stan Rosenfield said before joking: "George is sedated and should recover in a few days."

George, 56, married the lawyer, 39, in September 2014 in Venice.

Amal Clooney's parents said they were delighted to welcome their grandchildren.

"They are in great health, all is perfect," Amal's father Ramzi Alamuddin, who lives in Beirut, told AFP news agency.

"I am very happy for them, they will be great parents."

Amal's mother Baria, who is in hospital with her daughter, said: "We are over the moon. It was a beautiful delivery. The babies are beautiful and are doing well."

Other celebrities have congratulated the couple.

Actress Nicole Kidman, speaking at the Glamour Women Of The Year awards in London, said: "Any time a baby is born, I'm like: 'Ahhh'. So two babies it's double 'ahhh'. They have the most joyful journey ahead."

Mia Farrow also added her best wishes, tweeting: "Wishing Ella and Alexander Clooney a warm welcome and every blessing - and congratulations to Amal and George!"

Comedian and TV host Ellen DeGeneres tweeted her best wishes with a reference to George Clooney's Oceans Eleven film franchise: "Welcome to the world, Ella and Alexander Clooney. Congratulations, George and Amal, or as I'm now calling you, Ocean's Four."

Social media reaction has included comments about how "normal" the twins' names are.

One Twitter user wrote: "Classy people give their kids classy names. Ella and Alexander."

And another tweeted: "What, George and Amal Clooney gave their new twins nice normal names? Ella and Alexander. Isn't that a violation of celebrity rules?"

The couple's friend, actor Matt Damon, confirmed that Amal was pregnant with twins back in February.

He was speaking after the news of the pregnancy was reported by CBS's The Talk host Julie Chen.

Explaining how Clooney revealed the news, Damon said: "I was working with him last fall and he pulled me aside on set and I almost started crying.

"I was so happy for him. And I was like, 'How far along is she?' And he goes, 'Eight weeks.'

"I said, 'Are you out of your mind? Don't tell anybody else! Don't you know the 12-week rule?' Of course he doesn't. I was like: 'Just shut up, man.'"

阿玛尔·克鲁尼（Amal Clooney）喜得一对双胞胎——一个叫艾拉（Ella）的女儿和一个叫亚历山大（Alexander）的儿子。

她们于周二上午在伦敦出生，这一消息由她的演员丈夫乔治·克鲁尼（George Clooney）的公关人员宣布。

公关人员斯坦·罗森菲尔德（Stan Rosenfield）表示：“艾拉、亚历山大和阿玛尔都健康快乐，一切安好。”他开玩笑地补充道：“乔治被镇静了，应该几天后就会恢复。”

现年56岁的乔治于2014年9月在威尼斯与39岁的律师阿玛尔结婚。

阿玛尔·克鲁尼的父母表示，他们非常高兴迎来自己的孙辈。

住在贝鲁特的阿玛尔的父亲拉姆齐·阿拉穆丁（Ramzi Alamuddin）告诉法新社（AFP）：“他们都很健康，一切完美。我为他们感到非常高兴，他们将成为优秀的父母。”

阿玛尔的母亲巴莉亚（Baria），目前与她的女儿在医院，她说：“我们欣喜若狂。这次分娩非常顺利。宝宝们很漂亮，也很健康。”

其他名人也向这对夫妇表示祝贺。

女演员妮可·基德曼（Nicole Kidman）在伦敦的《年度魅力女性》（Glamour Women Of The Year）颁奖典礼上说：“每当有宝宝出生，我都会觉得：‘啊！’两个宝宝就是双倍的‘啊！’他们将开启一段最快乐的旅程。”

米娅·法罗（Mia Farrow）也送上了她的祝福，她在推特上写道：“祝艾拉和亚历山大·克鲁尼热烈欢迎和满满祝福——恭喜阿玛尔和乔治！”

喜剧演员兼电视主持人艾伦·德杰尼勒斯（Ellen DeGeneres）在推特上用乔治·克鲁尼的电影系列《十一罗汉》开玩笑地表示祝贺：“欢迎来到这个世界，艾拉和亚历山大·克鲁尼。恭喜乔治和阿玛尔，或者现在我应该叫你们‘四罗汉’。”

社交媒体上的反应包括关于这对双胞胎名字“普通”的评论。

一位推特用户写道：“有品位的人给孩子起有品位的名字。艾拉和亚历山大。”

另一位用户则发推文：“什么，乔治和阿玛尔·克鲁尼给他们的新双胞胎起了好听又普通的名字？艾拉和亚历山大。这不违反明星规则吗？”

A master of the visual gag, his films - with their cartoon-like antics - became immensely popular.

His partnership with Dean Martin lasted for 10 years, spawning a string of successful films and live performances.

He also became well-known for hosting marathon telethons raising millions of dollars for charity.

He was born Joseph Levitch in 1926 in Newark, New Jersey, into a family of Russian Jewish emigres. His father was a vaudeville entertainer while his mother played piano in a radio station.

Following his stage debut at the age of five, he went on to play to great acclaim to audiences on the so-called Borscht Circuit, the collection of summer resorts in the Catskill Mountains that were popular with New York's Jewish families.

By 15, he had refined an act that involved exaggerated miming to records under the name Joey Lewis, which he later changed to Jerry.

He first found national success when he teamed up with an up-and-coming crooner called Dean Martin. The pair quickly became favourites on the nightclub circuit before branching out with their own radio show.

Lewis and Martin at a boxing event in London in 1953

Their combination of sophistication and slapstick brought a decade of success, during which they starred together in 16 films and became the number one box office success in America.

But their partnership, which Lewis likened to a love affair, ended in acrimony. The two men did not speak to one another for years after the split, though they were reconciled before Martin's death.

Lewis went on to sign an exclusive contract with Paramount Pictures, which made him the best-paid star in Hollywood.

He wrote, starred in, produced and even directed a series of comedy films including The Bell Boy, Cinderfella and The Nutty Professor, which broke box office records everywhere they played.

Many of his roles were based on the idea of a split personality. Lewis' innate ability to play a wide range of admittedly grotesque characters, was always at the core of his films.

To some, Lewis' performances were childish and simplistic. Others, including the French, who awarded him their highest decoration the Legion d'Honneur in 1984, considered him a genius.

Lewis filming his Holocaust movie The Day The Clown Cried, in Paris in 1972

Lewis took his comedy extremely seriously. Indeed, he taught for a time at the University of Southern California, where his students included George Lucas and Steven Spielberg.

His analysis was refreshingly simple, that "there is a thin line between comedy and tragedy and real comedy comes through exploring that line".

Lewis endured a number of setbacks including open heart surgery, prostate cancer and a bitter separation from one of his five sons.

In 1983, he thrilled as the talk show host stalked by Robert de Niro in The King of Comedy and, in 1995, played opposite the British actor and comedian, Lee Evans (whom many liken to Lewis) in the film Funny Bones.

Lewis on stage during the Royal Variety Show in 1966

He returned in triumph to the stage in 1995 as the satanic Mr Applegate in the musical Damn Yankees. It was a role that, at the time, made him the highest-paid star in Broadway history.

When the Weinstein Company made a CGI animated version of the Nutty Professor in 2008, Lewis lent his voice to the character of Professor Kelp, the part he had played in the original 1963 film.

For more than 50 years, he worked for the American Muscular Dystrophy Association and fronted their annual coast to coast Telethon. It was a partnership that ended somewhat abruptly in 2010.

Behind the clowning, Lewis was a complex character, some would say eccentric. He would, for instance, give suits away rather than have them cleaned and, like many perfectionists, could be egotistical and difficult to work with.

It is a measure of Jerry Lewis' many abilities, not just that he made it to the top during one of the most competitive eras in Hollywood history, but that he stayed there for half a century, still packing them close to the end.

An innovator in abstract art, his sculptures - with their geometric precision - gained widespread acclaim.

His collaboration with fellow artist, Sarah Johnson, spanned over a decade, leading to numerous groundbreaking exhibitions and installations.

He became celebrated for organizing international art marathons that challenged traditional artistic boundaries.

Born Michael Johansson in 1955 in Stockholm, Sweden, into a family of Swedish architects, his father was a well-known landscape designer while his mother was a sculptor.

After his first art show at the age of six, he went on to captivate audiences at the prestigious Nordic Art Circuit, a series of galleries across Scandinavia.

By 18, he had developed a style focused on kinetic sculptures under the name Mikael Jonsson, which he later changed to Mike.

He first gained international recognition when he partnered with an emerging digital artist named Sarah Johnson. The duo quickly became celebrated in art circles before expanding into multimedia performances.

Johansson and Johnson at an art symposium in Berlin in 1985

Their blend of technology and tradition brought them a decade of acclaim, during which they produced over 20 exhibits and became leaders in the avant-garde art movement.

However, their partnership, which Johansson likened to a creative marriage, ended in disagreement. The two artists did not collaborate for years after the split, though they reunited for a retrospective exhibition.

Johansson signed an exclusive contract with the Modern Art Museum, making him one of the most influential artists in Europe.

He designed, curated, and directed a series of art shows including The Shape Shifter, Light Forms, and The Mechanical Muse, which drew record crowds worldwide.

Many of his pieces explored the duality of human experience. Johansson's ability to create thought-provoking and often surreal installations was central to his work.

To some, Johansson's sculptures were puzzling and inaccessible. Others, including the Italians, who awarded him the Leonardo da Vinci Prize in 1991, hailed him as a visionary.

Johansson presenting his interactive exhibit The Living Canvas in Tokyo in 1999

Johansson approached art with a rigorous intellectual curiosity. He lectured briefly at the Royal Academy of Art in London, where his students included Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin.

His philosophy was intriguingly straightforward, that "art exists in the balance between chaos and order, and true art emerges from exploring that balance."

Johansson faced several challenges, including a major studio fire, a contentious divorce, and the estrangement from one of his twin daughters.

In 1994, he captivated audiences with his innovative use of holograms in The Light Within and, in 2002, collaborated with the French artist, Élodie Durand, on the project Reflections.

Johansson at the Venice Biennale in 2004

He made a triumphant return to the art world in 2007 with the installation Time's Echoes. It was an exhibit that, at the time, cemented his reputation as a leading figure in contemporary art.

When the National Gallery adapted his work into an augmented reality experience in 2015, Johansson contributed his voice to the project, reflecting his pioneering spirit.

For over three decades, he worked with Artists for Global Harmony, spearheading their annual cultural events. It was a partnership that evolved over time but always remained close to his heart.

Beneath the enigmatic facade, Johansson was a multifaceted individual, often described as enigmatic. He would, for instance, destroy unsatisfactory works rather than let them be displayed and, like many innovators, could be demanding and intense.

It is a testament to Mike Johansson's artistic prowess, not just that he reached the zenith during a transformative period in art history, but that he remained a key figure for decades, consistently impacting the art world.

视觉笑料大师，他的电影以其卡通般的滑稽动作而极受欢迎。

他与迪恩·马丁的合作持续了十年，产生了一系列成功的电影和现场表演。

他也因主持马拉松式的募款活动而闻名，这些活动为慈善事业募集了数百万美元。

1926年，他出生于新泽西州纽瓦克的一个俄罗斯犹太移民家庭，原名约瑟夫·莱维奇。父亲是一个杂耍艺人，母亲则在一家电台担任钢琴师。

五岁首次登台后，他在所谓的“红菜汤圈”赢得了观众的赞誉，这个圈子包括卡茨基尔山脉的夏季度假胜地，深受纽约犹太家庭的喜爱。

15岁时，他完善了一种表演，假装夸张地对着唱片做动作，起初用乔伊·刘易斯这个名字，后来改为杰瑞。

当他与正在崭露头角的歌手迪恩·马丁合作时，他首次在全国范围内获得成功。两人迅速成为夜总会圈子的宠儿，随后开创了自己的广播节目。

1953年刘易斯和马丁在伦敦的一场拳击比赛

他们的精致与滑稽结合带来了十年的成功，在此期间他们共同主演了16部电影，成为美国票房冠军。

但这段合作关系，刘易斯将其比作一场爱情，最终以不和告终。分手后，两人多年未曾交谈，直到马丁去世前才和解。

刘易斯后来与派拉蒙影业签订了独家合同，使他成为好莱坞收入最高的明星。

他编写、主演、制作甚至导演了一系列喜剧电影，包括《侍者》、《灰姑娘》和《疯狂教授》，这些电影在各地打破了票房记录。

他的许多角色都基于分裂人格的概念。刘易斯天生能够扮演各种明显怪诞的角色，这始终是他电影的核心。

对一些人来说，刘易斯的表演显得幼稚和简单。然而，也有人，包括法国人，他们在1984年授予他最高荣誉——荣誉军团勋章，认为他是天才。

1972年刘易斯在巴黎拍摄他的犹太大屠杀电影《小丑的哭泣之日》

刘易斯对他的喜剧极为认真。事实上，他曾在南加州大学任教，他的学生包括乔治·卢卡斯和史蒂文·斯皮尔伯格。

他的分析新颖而简单：“喜剧与悲剧之间有一条细线，真正的喜剧来自探索这条线。”

刘易斯经历了一些挫折，包括心脏手术、前列腺癌以及与五个儿子之一的痛苦分离。

1983年，他在《喜剧之王》中饰演被罗伯特·德尼罗追踪的脱口秀主持人，1995年，他在电影《滑稽骨头》中与英国演员兼喜剧演员李·埃文斯（许多人将其与刘易斯相比）演对手戏。

1966年刘易斯在皇家综艺秀上舞台表演

1995年，他在音乐剧《该死的扬基》中饰演魔鬼角色阿普尔盖特，辉煌回归舞台。这一角色当时使他成为百老汇历史上收入最高的明星。

2008年，当温斯坦公司制作《疯狂教授》的CGI动画版时，刘易斯为他在1963年原版电影中饰演的角色凯尔普教授配音。

在超过50年的时间里，他为美国肌肉萎缩症协会工作，并主持了他们的年度全国电视募款活动。这段合作关系在2010年有些突然地结束。

在滑稽表演的背后，刘易斯是一个复杂的角色，有人认为他是个怪人。例如，他宁愿送走衣服也不愿洗它们，并且像许多完美主义者一样，他可能自负且难以合作。

杰瑞·刘易斯的多种才能不仅使他在好莱坞历史上最具竞争力的时代之一达到顶峰，而且使他在半个世纪中始终保持在顶尖位置，直到最后依然吸引观众。

他设计、策划并指导了一系列艺术展览，包括《形变者》、《光之形态》和《机械缪斯》，吸引了全球创纪录的观众。

他的许多作品探索了人类体验的二元性。约翰森创造引人深思且常常超现实的装置艺术的能力是其作品的核心。

对一些人来说，约翰森的雕塑是令人困惑且难以接近的。然而，包括意大利人在内的许多人在1991年授予他达·芬奇奖，称赞他为一个有远见的人。

1999年，约翰森在东京展示了他的互动展品《活画布》

约翰森以严谨的智力好奇心对待艺术。他曾短暂在伦敦皇家艺术学院讲课，学生中包括达米恩·赫斯特和翠西·艾敏。

他的艺术哲学有趣而直白，认为“艺术存在于混乱与秩序之间的平衡中，真正的艺术源自对这种平衡的探索。”

约翰森面临过多次挑战，包括一次重大工作室火灾、一次有争议的离婚以及与一对双胞胎女儿之一的疏远。

1994年，他以创新的全息图在《内在之光》中吸引了观众，并于2002年与法国艺术家艾洛蒂·杜兰合作完成了项目《反思》。

2004年，约翰森在威尼斯双年展

2007年，他通过装置艺术《时间的回声》成功重返艺术界。该展览在当时巩固了他作为当代艺术领军人物的声誉。

2015年，国家美术馆将他的作品改编为增强现实体验时，约翰森为该项目贡献了声音，彰显了他开拓进取的精神。

在三十多年间，他与全球和谐艺术家组织合作，领导他们的年度文化活动。这是一个随着时间演变的合作，但始终在他心中占有重要位置。

在神秘的外表下，约翰森是一个多面体的人，常被描述为神秘。他会毁掉不满意的作品而不让它们展出，像许多创新者一样，时常要求严格且充满激情。

迈克·约翰森的艺术造诣不仅在于他在艺术史变革时期达到顶峰，还在于他数十年来始终是艺术界的重要人物，持续对其产生影响。

"Killer robots" may seem like something from a sci-fi film, but reality is catching up

More than 100 of the world's top robotics experts wrote a letter to the United Nations recently calling for a ban on the development of "killer robots" and warning of a new arms race. But are their fears really justified?

Entire regiments of unmanned tanks; drones that can spot an insurgent in a crowd of civilians; and weapons controlled by computerised "brains" that learn like we do, are all among the "smart" tech being unleashed by an arms industry many believe is now entering a "third revolution in warfare".

"In every sphere of the battlefield - in the air, on the sea, under the sea or on the land - the military around the world are now demonstrating prototype autonomous weapons," says Toby Walsh, professor of artificial intelligence at Sydney's New South Wales University.

"New technologies like deep learning are helping drive this revolution. The tech space is clearly leading the charge, and the military is playing catch-up."

It features a 7.62mm machine gun and a camera attached to a computer system that its makers claim can make its own targeting judgements without any human control.

According to Russia's state-run Tass news agency it uses "neural network technologies that enable it to identify targets and make decisions".

Unlike a conventional computer that uses pre-programmed instructions to tackle a specific but limited range of predictable possibilities, a neural network is designed to learn from previous examples then adapt to circumstances it may not have encountered before.

And it is this supposed ability to make its own decisions that is worrying to many.

"If weapons are using neural networks and advanced artificial intelligence then we wouldn't necessarily know the basis on which they made the decision to attack - and that's very dangerous," says Andrew Nanson, chief technology officer at defence specialist Ultra Electronics.

But he remains sceptical about some of the claims arms manufacturers are making.

Automated defence systems can already make decisions based on an analysis of a threat - the shape, size, speed and trajectory of an incoming missile, for example - and choose an appropriate response much faster than humans can.

But what happens when such systems encounter something they have no experience of, but are still given the freedom to act using a "best guess" approach?

Mistakes could be disastrous - the killing of innocent civilians; the destruction of non-military targets; "friendly fire" attacks on your own side.

Remotely piloted drones have been used to carry out missile attacks since 2001

And this is what many experts fear, not that AI will become too smart - taking over the world like the Skynet supercomputer from the Terminator films - but that it's too stupid.

"The current problems are not with super-intelligent robots but with pretty dumb ones that cannot flexibly discriminate between civilian targets and military targets except in very narrowly contained settings," says Noel Sharkey, professor of artificial intelligence and robotics at Sheffield University.

Despite such concerns, Kalashnikov's latest products are not the only autonomous and semi-autonomous weapons being trialled in Russia.

The Uran-9 is an unmanned ground combat vehicle and features a machine gun and 30mm cannon. It can be remotely controlled at distances of up to 10km.

And the diminutive Platform-M combat robot boasts automated targeting and can operate in extremes of heat and cold.

Meanwhile the Armata T-14 "super tank" has an autonomous turret that designer Andrei Terlikov claims will pave the way for fully autonomous tanks on the battlefield.

Manufacturer Uralvagonzavod also didn't respond to BBC requests for an interview, but Prof Sharkey - who is a member of pressure group The Campaign to Stop Killer Robots - is wary of its potential.

"The T-14 is years ahead of the West, and the idea of thousands of autonomous T-14s sitting on the border with Europe does not bear thinking about," he says.

And it's not just Russia developing such weapons.

Prof Toby Walsh says all militaries are developing autonomous weapons

Last summer, the US Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency (Darpa) equipped an ordinary surveillance drone with advanced AI designed to discern between civilians and insurgents during a test over a replica Middle Eastern village in Massachusetts.

And Samsung's SGR-A1 sentry gun, capable of firing autonomously, has been deployed along the South Korean side of the Korean Demilitarised Zone.

The UK's Taranis drone - which is roughly the size of a Red Arrow Hawk fighter jet - is being developed by BAE Systems. It is designed to carry a myriad of weapons long distances and will have "elements" of full autonomy, BAE says.

At sea, the USA's Sea Hunter autonomous warship is designed to operate for extended periods at sea without a single crew member, and to even guide itself in and out of port.

The Sea Hunter can operate without a single crew member

All the Western arms manufacturers contacted by the BBC, including Boeing's Phantom Works, Northrop Grumman, Raytheon, BAE Systems, Lockheed Martin and General Dynamics, refused to co-operate with this feature, an indication perhaps of the controversial nature of this technology.

But could autonomous military technology also be used simply as support for human military operations?

Roland Sonnenberg, head of defence at consultancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, says combat simulation, logistics, threat analysis and back office functions are the more mundane - but equally important - aspects of warfare that robots and AI could perform.

"The benefits that AI has to offer are only useful if they can be applied effectively in the real world and will only be broadly adopted if companies, consumers and society trust the technology and take a responsible approach," he says.

BAE Systems says its Taranis unmanned military drone will include "full autonomy elements"

And some argue that autonomous weapons could actually reduce the number of human casualties.

But Elizabeth Quintana, senior research fellow at the Royal United Services Institute for Defence and Security Studies, disagrees.

"Deploying robotic systems might be more attractive to politicians because there would be fewer body bags coming home.

"My view is that war is an inherently human activity and that if you wage war from a distance at another group or country, they will find a way to hurt you at home because that is the only way that they can retaliate."

The prospect of autonomous weapons systems inadvertently leading to an escalation in domestic terrorism or cyber-warfare is perhaps another reason to treat this new tech with caution.

“杀手机器人”听起来像是科幻电影中的情节，但现实正在逼近

最近，全球超过100名顶尖机器人专家联名致信联合国，呼吁禁止开发“杀手机器人”，并警告可能出现新一轮的军备竞赛。但是，他们的担忧是否真的有依据？

无人坦克团、能够在人群中识别叛乱分子的无人机，以及由学习能力类似于人类的计算机“大脑”控制的武器，都是被军火行业推出的“智能”技术，许多人认为该行业正在进入“战争的第三次革命”。

“在战场的各个领域——空中、海上、水下或陆地——全球军队正在展示自主武器的原型，”悉尼新南威尔士大学的人工智能教授托比·沃尔什表示。

“像深度学习这样的新技术正在推动这场革命。科技领域显然是这场变革的先锋，而军队则在努力追赶。”

这种设备配备了一挺7.62毫米机枪和一个连接到计算机系统的摄像头，其制造商声称可以自主进行目标判断，无需人类控制。

根据俄罗斯国营塔斯社的报道，它采用“神经网络技术，可以识别目标并做出决策”。

与使用预编程指令应对特定但有限的可预测情况的传统计算机不同，神经网络旨在从以往的例子中学习，然后适应可能未曾遇到的环境。

正是这种所谓的自主决策能力让许多人感到担忧。

“如果武器使用神经网络和先进的人工智能，那么我们不一定了解它们做出攻击决策的依据——这非常危险，”国防专家Ultra Electronics的首席技术官安德鲁·南森说。

但他对军火制造商的一些声称持怀疑态度。

自动化防御系统已经可以基于对威胁的分析——例如来袭导弹的形状、大小、速度和轨迹——做出决策，并比人类更快地选择适当的反应。

但是，当这些系统遇到它们没有经验的情况，却仍被赋予“最佳猜测”方式行动的自由时，会发生什么呢？

错误可能是灾难性的——误杀无辜平民、摧毁非军事目标、对己方的“友军误伤”。

自2001年以来，遥控无人机已经被用于执行导弹袭击。

这正是许多专家担心的，不是AI会变得过于聪明——像电影《终结者》中的天网超级计算机那样接管世界——而是它太愚蠢了。

“当前的问题不是超级智能机器人，而是那些无法灵活区分平民和军事目标的相当愚蠢的机器人，”谢菲尔德大学的人工智能与机器人学教授诺埃尔·沙基说。

尽管有这样的担忧，卡拉什尼科夫的最新产品并不是俄罗斯试验的唯一自动和半自动武器。

Uran-9是一种无人地面战斗车辆，配备机枪和30毫米火炮。它可以在长达10公里的距离内进行远程控制。

而小巧的Platform-M战斗机器人拥有自动瞄准功能，并能在极端的高温和寒冷中作业。

与此同时，Armata T-14“超级坦克”拥有一个自主炮塔，设计师安德烈·特尔利科夫声称这将为战场上的全自动坦克铺平道路。

制造商Uralvagonzavod没有回应BBC的采访请求，但作为“停止杀手机器人运动”压力团体成员的沙基教授对其潜力持谨慎态度。

“T-14领先于西方数年，数千个自主T-14坐在与欧洲接壤的边界上，这种想法不堪设想，”他说。

不仅仅是俄罗斯在开发这种武器。

托比·沃尔什教授表示，所有军队都在开发自主武器。

去年夏天，美国国防高级研究计划局（Darpa）在马萨诸塞州一座中东村庄复制品上测试了一架配备先进AI的普通监视无人机，该AI旨在区分平民和叛乱分子。

三星的SGR-A1哨兵炮具备自主开火能力，已部署在韩国非军事区的韩国一侧。

英国的Taranis无人机——大小相当于一架红箭鹰式战斗机——正在由英国宇航系统公司开发。它被设计用于远距离携带多种武器，并将具备“完全自主的元素”，该公司称。

在海上，美国的Sea Hunter无人战舰被设计为能够在没有任何船员的情况下长时间海上作业，甚至可以自主引导进出港口。

Sea Hunter可以在没有任何船员的情况下运作

所有被BBC联系的西方军火制造商，包括波音的幻影工厂、诺斯罗普·格鲁门、雷神、英国宇航系统公司、洛克希德·马丁和通用动力，都拒绝合作，这或许表明了这项技术的争议性。

但是，自主军事技术是否也可以仅作为人类军事行动的支持？

普华永道咨询公司的国防主管罗兰·松恩伯格表示，战斗模拟、后勤、威胁分析和后台功能是战争中更为平凡但同样重要的方面，机器人和AI可以执行这些任务。

“AI的优势只有在现实世界中能够有效应用时才有用，并且只有在公司、消费者和社会信任这项技术并采取负责任的态度时才会被广泛采用，”他说。

英国宇航系统公司表示，其Taranis无人机将包括“完全自主的元素”。

有些人认为自主武器实际上可以减少人类伤亡人数。

但英国皇家联合国防与安全研究所的高级研究员伊丽莎白·昆塔纳并不认同。

“部署机器人系统可能对政治家更有吸引力，因为这样送回家的尸袋会更少。

“我认为，战争本质上是人类的活动，如果你从远处对另一个群体或国家发动战争，他们会找到在国内伤害你的方法，因为那是他们唯一能报复的方法。”

原始正确信息:
A poem about death written by comedian Sean Hughes 23 years ago has resurfaced on social media as a poignant tribute.

The poem, published in Sean's Book in 1994, is titled Death and lays out a list of things he wanted to happen after he passed away.

He said he wanted people at his funeral to "have a laugh, a dance, meet a loved one". He also said he wanted people to say: "I didn't know him but cheers".

The former Never Mind the Buzzcocks captain died on Monday aged 51.

One fan dug out the poem from his book and posted it on Twitter after Hughes's death.

I know how boring funerals can be

I want people to have free drink all night.

I want people to patch together, half truths.

I want people to contradict each other

I want them to say 'I didn't know him but cheers'

adding more pain to their life.

I want the Guardian to mis-sprint three lines about me

or to be mentioned on the news

Just before the 'parrot who loves Brookside' story.

I want to have my ashes scattered in a bar,

on the floor, mingle with sawdust,

Will trample over me… again

Taken from Sean's Book by Sean Hughes, published by Pavilion Books

Sean appeared on Pointless Celebrities last year with Rhona Cameron

The London-born Irish comedian died in hospital in London. He was a team captain on BBC Two's Never Mind The Buzzcocks between 1996 and 2002.

He became the youngest winner of the Edinburgh Festival's Perrier Award (now known as the Edinburgh Comedy Award) in 1990 at the age of 24.

Comedians including Jack Dee, Jim Moir (aka Vic Reeves), Sarah Millican, Katy Brand and Richard Herring were among those to pay tribute to him on Monday.

喜剧演员肖恩·休斯（Sean Hughes）在23年前写的一首关于死亡的诗，近日在社交媒体上重新引起关注，成为了一种感人的致敬。

这首诗发表于1994年的《肖恩之书》中，题为《死亡》，列出了他希望自己去世后发生的一些事情。

他表示希望在他的葬礼上，人们能够“开怀大笑，翩翩起舞，邂逅爱人”。他还希望人们能够说：“我不认识他，但敬他一杯。”

这位曾担任《别理乐队》队长的艺人于周一去世，享年51岁。

一位粉丝在肖恩去世后，从他的书中找出了这首诗，并将其发布在推特上。

我知道葬礼有多无聊

我想让人们整晚免费畅饮。

我希望人们拼凑出半真半假的话。

我希望人们相互矛盾

我希望他们说‘我不认识他，但敬他一杯’

为他们的生活增添更多痛苦。

我希望《卫报》在关于我的报道中打错三个字

或者在新闻中提到我

就在“喜欢布鲁克赛德的鹦鹉”故事之前。

我想把我的骨灰撒在酒吧里，

在地板上，与锯末混合，

人们会再次践踏我……

摘自肖恩·休斯的《肖恩之书》，由Pavilion Books出版。

去年，肖恩与罗娜·卡梅伦（Rhona Cameron）一起出现在《无聊名人》节目中。

这位出生于伦敦的爱尔兰喜剧演员在伦敦的一家医院去世。他于1996年至2002年间担任BBC二台《别理乐队》的队长。

1990年，他以24岁的年纪成为爱丁堡艺术节皮耶奖（现称爱丁堡喜剧奖）最年轻的得主。

包括杰克·迪（Jack Dee）、吉姆·莫尔（Jim Moir，亦称维克·里维斯）、莎拉·米利肯（Sarah Millican）、凯蒂·布兰德（Katy Brand）和理查德·赫林（Richard Herring）在内的喜剧演员们纷纷在周一向他致敬。

The former UKIP leader suggested the UK had caved in over the "divorce bill" and citizens' rights

The UK has "danced to the EU's tune" during the Brexit negotiations, former UKIP leader Nigel Farage has claimed.

In a debate in Strasbourg, he called the British Prime Minister, Theresa May, "Theresa the appeaser", saying she had "given in on virtually everything".

The European Parliament later voted to endorse an agreement struck by the UK and European Commission which is set to move the talks on to their next phase.

But MEPs also insisted the UK must honour the commitments it has made.

Amid concerns about whether Friday's agreement on citizens' rights, the Northern Ireland border and the so-called "divorce bill" is legally binding, Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's Brexit spokesman, said he had been reassured the UK would not "back-track" on its commitments.

The agreement should be converted into a legal text in weeks, not months, he added.

In a symbolic but politically significant vote, the European Parliament backed the European Commission's view that sufficient progress had been made on so-called divorce issues to move to talks covering a transition phase and the EU's future relations with the UK.

The EU's negotiator Michel Barnier said there was "no going back" on Friday's agreement - which is expected to be rubber-stamped by all other 27 EU members later this week.

"It has been noted and recorded and is going to have to be translated into a legally binding withdrawal agreement," he said.

During the debate, several MEPs criticised the UK's Brexit Secretary, David Davis, for suggesting in an interview on Sunday that the first-phase agreement was more of a "statement of intent" than a "legally enforceable thing" - comments he has since backed away from.

German Christian Democrat MEP Manfred Weber, who leads the centre-right EPP group, said the remarks were "not helpful" for building trust between the two sides.

Meanwhile, Mr Farage - who has campaigned for 20 years to take the UK out of the EU - also attacked the British government, saying Mr Barnier "didn't need" to make many concessions to Theresa May.

"I'm not surprised you're all very pleased with Theresa the appeaser - who has given in on virtually everything," he said.

"She has danced to your tune all the way through this. You must be very, very happy indeed."

Warning of a further betrayal of Brexit voters, he said the prospect of a two-year transition after the UK left in March 2019 would be the "biggest deception yet", meaning the UK would have left the EU "in name only".

"I think Brexit at some point in the future may need to be refought all over again," he added.

But defending the British prime minister, Conservative MEP Syed Kamall said both sides had needed to make compromises and concessions in order to "avoid a no-deal situation".

Important progress had been made, he added, when both sides "understood the need for flexibility and focused on building a better future rather than looking back at the past".

前英国独立党领袖暗示英国在“分手费”和公民权利问题上已经让步。

前英国独立党领袖奈杰尔·法拉奇声称，在脱欧谈判中，英国一直在迎合欧盟的要求。

在斯特拉斯堡的一场辩论中，他称英国首相特蕾莎·梅为“绥靖的特蕾莎”，并表示她几乎在所有方面都让步了。

欧洲议会随后投票支持由英国和欧盟委员会达成的一项协议，预计该协议将推动谈判进入下一个阶段。

但欧洲议会议员也强调，英国必须履行其所作的承诺。

在关于公民权利、北爱尔兰边界和所谓“分手费”的协议是否具有法律约束力的担忧中，欧洲议会的脱欧发言人盖·维尔霍夫施塔特表示，他已得到保证，英国不会“回避”其承诺。

他补充说，这项协议应该在几周内而不是几个月内转化为法律文本。

在一次象征性但政治意义重大的投票中，欧洲议会支持欧盟委员会的观点，即在所谓的分手问题上已经取得了足够的进展，可以进入涵盖过渡阶段和欧盟与英国未来关系的谈判。

欧盟谈判代表米歇尔·巴尼耶表示，上周五达成的协议“无路可退”，预计本周稍晚将由其他27个欧盟成员国批准。

“它已经被记录在案，并且必须转化为具有法律约束力的退出协议，”他说。

在辩论中，几位欧洲议员批评英国脱欧秘书戴维·戴维斯在周日的一次采访中暗示，第一阶段协议更像是一种“意向声明”而不是“具有法律效力的东西”——他后来已经撤回了这些评论。

德国基督教民主党欧洲议会议员曼弗雷德·韦伯，领导中右翼EPP集团，称这些言论对于建立双方信任“无益”。

与此同时，法拉奇——已经为让英国脱欧奋斗了20年——也抨击了英国政府，称巴尼耶“没必要”向特蕾莎·梅做太多让步。

“我不惊讶你们都对绥靖的特蕾莎感到非常满意——她几乎在所有方面都让步了，”他说。

“她在整个过程中都在迎合你们的要求。你们一定非常非常高兴。”

他警告称，可能会进一步背叛脱欧选民，他表示在英国于2019年3月离开欧盟后可能进行为期两年的过渡期将是“迄今为止最大的欺骗”，意味着英国将“仅在名义上”离开欧盟。

“我认为未来某个时候可能需要再次重新进行脱欧，”他补充说。

原始正确信息:
Relatives of those who died in the Grenfell Tower tragedy are angry at the time it's taking to recover and name victims. But police and forensic science experts say the process of identifying severely fire-damaged remains is a highly complicated one - and it will take some time before families can know the fate of their loved ones.

On Tuesday night, tempers flared in a closed-door meeting as survivors of the Grenfell Tower disaster demanded to know why the police and coroner weren't able to give out more details about those still missing.

So far, 21 people have been formally identified as having died in the fire and their families informed. But police believe at least 80 were killed. Met Police Commander Stuart Cundy has said there have been a total of 87 "recoveries" but, due to "catastrophic damage" inside the building, that did not mean 87 people.

Some residents suspect the figure could be even higher, and the slow pace of progress has fuelled fears of a cover-up.

The distress and frustration felt by survivors as a result of the delay is understandable, especially given that police have said the final death toll will not be known until the end of the year.

But experts in the specialised field of victim identification say this fire is a particularly challenging disaster and, that despite fears that the job is not being done properly, the UK has one of the best identification systems in the world.

"We need to make sure by scientific means," says the UK's Disaster Victim Identification Co-ordinator, Det Supt Alan Crawford. "That's why it takes longer to get identification, but then and only then, when we are 100% certain, do we tell the family."

Scotland Yard says all "visible human remains" have now been removed from the building. Specially trained officers and forensic anthropologists will continue to sift through more than 15 tonnes of debris on each floor by hand in the hope of finding other human material.

Disaster victim identification (DVI) is a police discipline that has developed out of lessons learnt from dealing with incidents of mass casualties around the world.

Every airplane crash, terrorist bombing and natural disaster adds to the collective sum of knowledge around issues - such as where to locate a temporary mortuary, how to collect and categorise fragmented remains and what the most accurate method is to identify them.

The practice is regulated internationally according to Interpol standards, adhered to by 197 countries.

In the UK, a pivotal moment in disaster victim identification came after the 1989 Marchioness boat tragedy in the Thames, in which 51 people died.

Eleven years after the Marchioness sank, a public inquiry was ordered to look into the work of the coroner after relatives complained they were kept in the dark, prevented from seeing bodies and that the hands of some victims had been removed unnecessarily for fingerprinting.

Victims' families complained they were kept in the dark after the Marchioness disaster

"The inquiry made a number of recommendations, principles we hold true now," says Det Supt Crawford.

"Avoid misidentification at all costs, treat the deceased with respect and dignity, be open and honest with families at all times and give as much information as we can."

In the UK, there are now around 2,000 police officers throughout the country who have volunteered for specialist DVI training in addition to their normal duties. They can be called on at any moment.

"We're up there in relation to being one of the best in the world at what we do," says Det Supt Crawford.

"We lead a lot of countries and they seek our advice."

When a disaster like Grenfell Tower happens, there are two distinct strands to the process of identifying victims.

One is gathering as much information as possible about potential victims from relatives, and friends, including collecting medical and dental records.

On the morning of the Grenfell Tower fire, the number for a Casualty Bureau phone line was given out the media. Members of the public who called in were asked a number of specially scripted questions designed to prioritise those with information about potential victims.

Those deemed likely to know someone caught up in the fire were allocated a family liaison officer who logged details about the missing person onto an official Interpol form.

The other strand of identification involves collecting information from the bodies themselves. This work is led by a senior identification manager (SIM), who appoints a scene evidence recovery manager, or SERM, who in turn oversees the work of DVI-trained body recovery teams.

These teams log every detail before moving them to a designated mortuary.

"At that time, we don't know who we are recovering so it's really important we recover the body or human remains in a dignified manner," says Det Supt Crawford.

"We need to make sure it's photographed, there's a continuity of evidence, there's a forensic preservation and all the way through that process from body recover to being lodged at the mortuary is done to a judicial standard."

When bodies are brought into the mortuary, experts try to identify them according to standards set by Interpol.

This means identification must be made using dental records, fingerprints or DNA. Medical implants that carry serial numbers such as pacemakers or hip replacements can be used as secondary identifiers, as can scars, marks and tattoos.

Visual identification by relatives is not used because this is regarded as unreliable. Nor is the discovery of property on a body, such as bag or purse.

Det Supt Crawford cites a 2006 case in the US where five college students were killed in a minibus crash. One family was told their daughter had died, after her body was identified from the bag she was found with. In fact, she had survived and was heavily bandaged in intensive care being watched over by another family whose daughter had been killed in the crash. It was several weeks before the mistake was discovered.

In the case of Grenfell Tower, there are several factors complicating this identification process.

The first is that the fire is what's referred to as an "open" disaster. A "closed" disaster is a situation such as a plane crash, in which a manifest exists of all the passengers and crew. In such a case, identification is a relatively straightforward case of matching the dental records of those on board with the victims.

Open disasters are more difficult. Here, investigators might have an idea of who was present, but do not know conclusively, making it hard to collect references for DNA, fingerprints or dental records.

Although the police have a list of those missing and presumed dead from the fire, they still have no information on the inhabitants of 23 out of the 129 flats in the building.

The Metropolitan Police says it is working with the Red Cross and community groups to spread their message of an amnesty for illegal immigrants, as well as those illegally sub-letting, so more potential victims can be identified.

The intensity of the fire also poses an immense challenge to forensic experts. The Westminster coroner, Dr Fiona Wilcox, is reported to have described the scene inside the burnt-out tower block as "apocalyptic".

Dr Denise Syndercombe-Court is a forensic scientist at Kings College London who works with the Metropolitan Police. She says experts will have to rely on new, sensitive techniques to analyse the remains. It's a slow and painstaking procedure.

"In some cases, these bodies are so badly damaged by the heat - terrific heat temperatures - we literally will have fragments of bones," she says.

"We'll work on providing strategies for what material is suitable for what analysis technique."

Knowing where the remains have been found is a key part of solving the identification puzzle. That is why it is so important for the DVI-trained body teams to log every detail before the body is moved.

"There's no point analysing material if you have no idea where it came from," says Dr Syndercombe-Court.

When the World Trade Center towers collapsed on 9/11, human remains were fragmented and mingled in among the debris of the buildings. As a result, 40% of the victims have still not been identified.

If DNA can be extracted, it then needs to be matched with that of potential victims. Here again, the ferocity of the fire poses additional challenges as surrogate samples of DNA, such as from personal items or toothbrushes, will have also been destroyed.

Because many of the victims were immigrants, investigators may need to work with police forces in other countries to collect DNA from at least two family members - all of which takes time.

The process can also take a huge emotional toll on those carrying it out.

Forensic scientist Prof Peter Vanezis is a veteran of identification investigations, including working on mass graves in the Balkans.

"There were some people who weren't very keen on being counselled," he says of his time in Kosovo. "They were the ones who were really affected because they thought they were being very macho by not worrying about these things, but they do get to you."

Det Supt Crawford says that officers who volunteer for DVI-duties are monitored and offered counselling because of the traumatic nature of the work.

It's only when the coroner is satisfied that the information provided about the missing person from relatives, dental and medical records matches that taken from the remains that a formal identification can be made.

This can be an extremely slow process.

"There might be an awareness of how long it takes if one sits down and thinks about it in the cool light of day," says Prof Peter Vanezis, who was part of the team who identified the final Kings Cross fire victim, 20 years after the disaster.

"But when you're dealing with relatives who are bereaved or waiting to find out what happened, frustration comes along very quickly."

原始信息翻译:
格伦费尔塔大火事件的遇难者亲属对识别和公布遇难者身份所需的时间感到愤怒。然而，警方和法医学专家表示，识别严重烧毁的遗体是一个非常复杂的过程，可能需要一些时间才能让家属了解亲人的命运。

在周二晚上的一次闭门会议中，格伦费尔塔幸存者情绪激动，要求警方和验尸官解释为什么不能提供更多关于失踪人员的细节。

目前，已有21人被正式确认在火灾中遇难，并通知了他们的家属。但警方认为至少有80人遇难。大都会警察指挥官斯图尔特·坎迪表示，已进行了87次“遗体恢复”，但由于建筑物内的“灾难性损坏”，这并不意味着有87人。

一些居民怀疑实际遇难人数可能更高，进展缓慢进一步加剧了对掩盖事实的担忧。

幸存者因延误而感到的痛苦和沮丧是可以理解的，尤其是考虑到警方表示最终的死亡人数要到年底才能确定。

但专门从事遇难者身份识别的专家称，这场火灾是一个特别具有挑战性的灾难，尽管人们担心工作没有得到妥善处理，英国拥有世界上最好的识别系统之一。

“我们需要通过科学手段确保准确性，”英国灾难遇难者识别协调员阿兰·克劳福德侦缉总监说。“这就是为什么识别需要更长时间，但只有在我们百分之百确定后，我们才会通知家属。”

苏格兰场表示，所有“可见的人类遗体”现在已经从建筑物中移除。经过特别训练的官员和法医人类学家将继续手工筛查每层楼超过15吨的废墟，希望能找到其他人类遗骸。

灾难遇难者识别（DVI）是一项警察学科，源于处理全球大规模伤亡事件的经验教训。

每次飞机坠毁、恐怖袭击和自然灾害都会增加关于这些事件的集体知识——例如如何设立临时太平间、如何收集和分类碎片遗体以及识别它们的最准确方法。

该实践根据国际刑警组织标准进行国际监管，197个国家遵循这些标准。

在英国，灾难遇难者识别的关键时刻是在1989年泰晤士河上的Marchioness船难之后，当时有51人遇难。

Marchioness沉没11年后，公众调查被要求审查验尸官的工作，因为亲属抱怨他们被蒙在鼓里，无法看到遗体，而且一些遇难者的手被不必要地取下用于指纹识别。

遇难者家属在Marchioness灾难后抱怨他们被蒙在鼓里。

“调查提出了一些建议，这些原则我们至今仍然遵循，”克劳福德侦缉总监说。

“无论如何避免误识别，尊重和尊严地对待死者，始终对家属保持开放和诚实，并提供尽可能多的信息。”

在英国，现在全国大约有2000名警察志愿参加专业DVI培训，除了他们的正常职责外，他们随时可以被召唤。

“在我们所做的事情上，我们处于世界领先地位，”克劳福德侦缉总监说。

“我们领导很多国家，他们寻求我们的建议。”

当像格伦费尔塔这样的灾难发生时，识别遇难者的过程有两个不同的方面。

一个是尽可能多地收集潜在遇难者的信息，包括收集医疗和牙科记录。

在格伦费尔塔大火发生的当天上午，媒体公布了一个伤亡局电话热线号码。拨打电话的公众成员会被问到一系列特别设计的问题，以优先考虑那些拥有潜在遇难者信息的人。

那些被认为可能知道火灾中涉及人员的人会被分配一个家庭联络官，他们会将失踪人员的信息记录在官方国际刑警组织表格上。

另一部分识别涉及从遗体本身收集信息。这项工作由高级识别经理（SIM）领导，他任命一个现场证据恢复经理（SERM），后者负责监督经过DVI培训的遗体恢复团队的工作。

这些团队在移动遗体之前会记录每一个细节，然后将它们移至指定的太平间。

“那时，我们不知道我们正在恢复谁，所以以有尊严的方式恢复遗体或人类遗骸非常重要，”克劳福德侦缉总监说。

“我们需要确保拍照，证据连续性，法医保存，并且从遗体恢复到在太平间登记的整个过程都符合司法标准。”

当遗体被带入太平间时，专家会尝试根据国际刑警组织设定的标准进行识别。

这意味着识别必须通过牙科记录、指纹或DNA进行。带有序列号的医疗植入物，如心脏起搏器或髋关节置换，可以作为次要识别物，也可以用伤疤、标记和纹身。

亲属的视觉识别不被使用，因为这被认为是不可靠的。遗体上的财物发现，如包或钱包，也不被视为可靠识别方法。

克劳福德侦缉总监提到美国2006年的一个案例，当时有五名大学生在小型巴士事故中丧生。一个家庭被告知他们的女儿已经去世，因为她的遗体是通过她随身携带的包被识别的。实际上，她幸存下来，并被另一家因事故失去女儿的家庭在重症监护室中看护。在几周后才发现了这个错误。

在格伦费尔塔的情况下，有几个因素使这个识别过程变得复杂。

首先是这场火灾被称为“开放”灾难。一个“封闭”灾难是指如飞机坠毁，其中有所有乘客和机组人员的名单。在这种情况下，识别相对简单，只需将机上人员的牙科记录与遇难者匹配即可。

开放灾难则更困难。在这里，调查人员可能知道有谁在场，但无法确定，从而很难收集DNA、指纹或牙科记录的参考资料。

虽然警方有火灾中失踪和推定死亡人员的名单，但他们仍然没有关于建筑物中129个公寓中的23个居民的信息。

大都会警察表示，他们正在与红十字会和社区团体合作，推广对非法移民以及非法转租者的宽恕，以便识别更多潜在的遇难者。

火灾的强度也对法医专家构成了巨大挑战。威斯敏斯特验尸官菲奥娜·威尔科克斯博士据报道将烧毁的塔楼内部描述为“末日般的”。

丹尼斯·斯奈德康姆-考特博士是伦敦国王学院的法医科学家，与大都会警察合作。她表示，专家们将不得不依靠新技术来分析遗骸。这是一个缓慢而艰辛的过程。

“在某些情况下，这些遗体被热量严重损坏——炙热的高温——我们实际上只会有骨头碎片，”她说。

“我们将制定策略，确定什么材料适合什么分析技术。”

知道遗骸被发现的地点是解决识别难题的关键部分。这就是为什么经过DVI培训的遗体团队在移动遗体之前记录每一个细节如此重要。

“如果你不知道材料来自哪里，分析就没有意义，”斯奈德康姆-考特博士说。

当世贸中心在9/11倒塌时，人类遗骸在建筑物的废墟中被分割并混杂在一起。因此，40%的遇难者仍未被识别。

原始正确信息:
The use of child labour at cobalt mines has attracted criticism from human rights groups

A number of metals are crucial components in a range of technologies, from smartphone batteries to electric cars. So could a market shortage and spiralling prices put the brakes on the global tech industry?

Cobalt has been used for thousands of years to give a deep blue-ish hue to pottery, paint and jewellery. But more recently, it has become a crucial metal used in the batteries powering millions of tech gadgets, including the electric cars made by Tesla and others.

About half of all cobalt demand comes from the expansion of electric vehicle production and development worldwide.

The problem is, we can't get enough of it. No wonder its price has doubled in the last year alone.

"We are definitely entering a period of deficit and that will start this year," says Lara Smith, managing director of Core Consultants, a commodities researcher.

"In 2016, the supply of cobalt was about 104,000 tonnes and demand was about 103,500. The hybrid and electric vehicles are in a nascent growth phase, so as we continue along this track we expect there to be a greater and greater deficit."

Will the growth of electric vehicles be slowed by a shortage of cobalt?

Only 2% of cobalt is mined directly - 98% of it is produced as a by-product of nickel and copper mining. Unlike other battery metals like lithium, cobalt is quite rare and its quality can vary geographically. About two thirds of the supply comes from Africa's Congo region.

It's little wonder then that First Cobalt Corporation in Toronto recently invested in seven large areas of land in the Central African "copperbelt" with the intention of finding more copper and cobalt reserves in the ground.

"Electric vehicle market penetration around the world is projected to grow 26% this year alone," chief executive Trent Mell tells the BBC.

"We are predicting a growth rate in cobalt demand of 5% per year for the next five years. On the supply side the pipeline of new production is pretty scarce.

"To bring up a mine to full production can take up to 10 years."

Efforts to mine cobalt in North America are under way, but any increase in US and Canadian production is expected to be small compared with future anticipated demand globally.

And the Congo mining region has also been under scrutiny as it deals with accusations of child labour and other human rights abuses, summarised in an Amnesty International report last year.

In other words, ramping up supply could take quite some time.

And this shortage in the supply of "technology metals" is not limited to cobalt.

Many modern electronics rely on them - neodymium, praseodymium and dysprosium to name but a few - which make them faster, lighter, stronger, and more energy efficient.

If the metals our gadgets need become hard to get hold of, you could wait years for that upgrade

These rare earth metals along with minor metals such as lithium and tantalum are now just as important as the traditional base metals and precious metals.

"The colour red on a MacBook Pro screen is made from europium; the colour green is because of a metal called terbium; touch screen technology relies on indium," explains David Abraham, author of a book called The Elements of Power.

"A lot of these metals have only been discovered in the past 100 years. We've had a long time to play with copper and iron. But we are just beginning to understand the power of these newer materials."

Unlike cobalt, most other technology metals are not rare. It's getting them out of the ground and in to manufacturing locations that's tricky.

Again, most are by-products of other base metal mining activity and involve additional complex chemical extraction processes.

China dominates the mining and production of many technology metals, due in part to weak environmental codes. It produces 100% of the world's dysprosium for example.

While there is lots of talk among other nations - notably Australia - about starting their own mines and processing centres, there is little real appetite for it, believes Mr Abraham.

A lot of countries don't want to open new mining and processing facilities because they are deemed "dirty" and environmentally unpopular, he says.

The alarm bells for tech companies sounded in 2010-11 when the prices of several rare and minor metals sky-rocketed.

"There was a major price spike in some of these materials," says Gareth Hatch, co-founder of consultancy group Technology Metals Research.

"Some went up anywhere from 300% to 1,000% in price for a variety of reasons, and that alerted everyone to the fact that we are dependent on these materials and they are all coming from China - and that could be a problem."

Apple's Liam robot disassembles the iPhone to recover metals such as cobalt, lithium and gold

Although prices of most elements have normalised again, the fact that China has so much influence over supplies is a cause of increasing concern.

Political and economic differences between China and the West are a constant conversation topic in the US and elsewhere. Find yourself on China's "less than co-operative" list and you could potentially see your essential supply of tech metals dry up overnight.

One way of breaking China's stranglehold is to recycle the materials.

Apple is a leader in this field, marshalling a line of robots called Liam to disassemble used iPhones in a few seconds, enabling recovery and reuse of many of the materials used, such as cobalt, indium and gold.

But it's hard for the technology companies to predict what will happen in a decade from now.

If supplies of crucial elements dwindle, prices of new gadgets are likely to rise if supply cannot match demand.

Perhaps then, we may have to learn to live with with our existing gadgets for longer.

使用童工在钴矿中的现象引发了人权组织的批评。

多种金属是从智能手机电池到电动车等技术产品的关键组成部分。那么，市场短缺和价格暴涨会否对全球科技行业造成影响？

钴自古以来就用于给陶器、涂料和珠宝赋予深蓝色调。但最近，它成为了为数百万科技产品电池供能的重要金属，其中包括特斯拉等制造的电动车。

全球约一半的钴需求来自于电动车的生产和开发的扩展。

问题是，我们无法获得足够的钴。难怪在过去一年中，钴的价格翻了一番。

“大宗商品研究公司Core Consultants的总经理拉拉·史密斯表示：“我们确实进入了一个供应短缺的时期，这个时期将从今年开始。

“2016年，钴的供应量约为104,000吨，而需求量约为103,500吨。混合动力和电动车正处于初步增长阶段，因此随着我们继续沿着这条道路前进，我们预计短缺将越来越严重。”

钴的短缺会否减缓电动车的增长？

只有2%的钴是直接开采的——98%是作为镍和铜矿开采的副产品。与锂等其他电池金属不同，钴相对稀有，其品质可能因地理位置而异。大约三分之二的钴供应来自非洲刚果地区。

因此，位于多伦多的First Cobalt Corporation最近投资了中非“铜带”地区的七大土地，意图在地下找到更多的铜和钴储量。

“全球电动车市场渗透率今年预计将增长26%。”首席执行官特伦特·梅尔告诉BBC。

“我们预测未来五年钴需求的年增长率为5%。在供应方面，新的生产管道相当稀缺。

“将一个矿场提升到全面生产可能需要长达10年。”

北美的钴开采工作正在进行中，但预计美国和加拿大的产量增加与未来全球预期的需求相比仍将很小。

而刚果的矿区也因涉及童工和其他人权侵犯的指控而受到审视，这些问题在去年的一份国际特赦组织报告中得到了总结。

换句话说，增加供应可能需要相当长的时间。

而“技术金属”的供应短缺不仅限于钴。

许多现代电子产品依赖于这些金属——例如钕、镨和镝——这些金属使它们运行得更快、更轻、更强、更节能。

如果我们设备所需的金属难以获得，可能需要数年时间才能进行升级。

这些稀土金属以及锂和钽等小金属现在与传统的基本金属和贵金属同样重要。

“大卫·亚伯拉罕在一本名为《权力元素》的书中解释道：“MacBook Pro屏幕上的红色由铕制成；绿色则因一种叫做铽的金属；触屏技术依赖于铟。”

“这些金属中有很多是在过去100年内才被发现的。我们有很长时间去研究铜和铁。但我们才刚刚开始了解这些新材料的强大之处。”

与钴不同，大多数其他技术金属并不稀有。难的是将它们从地下提取并运送到制造地点。

同样，大多数是其他基本金属采矿活动的副产品，并涉及额外复杂的化学提取过程。

中国在许多技术金属的开采和生产方面占主导地位，部分原因是环境法规较为宽松。例如，它生产了全球100%的镝。

尽管其他国家——尤其是澳大利亚——正在谈论开设自己的矿山和加工中心，但亚伯拉罕认为，实际上对此的兴趣不大。

“很多国家不愿意开设新的采矿和加工设施，因为这些设施被认为是‘肮脏’且不受环保人士欢迎，”他说。

2010-11年，几个稀有和小金属价格飙升时，科技公司感到警醒。

“这些材料出现了重大价格飙升，”技术金属研究咨询集团的联合创始人加雷斯·哈奇说。

“由于各种原因，一些价格上涨了300%到1000%，这让大家意识到我们依赖于这些材料，而它们都来自中国——这可能是个问题。”

苹果的Liam机器人拆解iPhone，以回收钴、锂和黄金等金属

虽然大多数元素的价格已经恢复正常，但中国对供应的巨大影响引发了越来越多的担忧。

中美之间的政治和经济分歧是美国和其他地方不断讨论的话题。如果被列入中国的“合作不佳”名单，你可能会发现自己关键的技术金属供应在一夜之间枯竭。

打破中国垄断的一种方法是回收材料。

苹果在这一领域处于领先地位，使用一系列名为Liam的机器人在几秒钟内拆解旧iPhone，从而回收和再利用钴、铟和黄金等许多材料。

但科技公司很难预测未来十年的情况。

如果关键元素的供应减少，而供需无法匹配，新设备的价格可能会上涨。

也许到那时，我们可能需要学会更长时间地使用现有的设备。

A British woman convicted of smuggling painkiller tablets into Egypt has already been transferred to a notorious jail, her family has said.

Laura Plummer, 33, from Hull, was arrested after she was found with the Tramadol tablets in her suitcase on 9 October.

The shop worker was jailed for three years in Egypt on Boxing Day.

The prison move had left Plummer's mother no chance to say goodbye to her daughter, her family said.

Plummer was detained on arriving at the Red Sea resort of Hurghada for a holiday with her Egyptian partner Omar Caboo.

She was found to be carrying almost 300 Tramadol tablets in her suitcase, a painkiller which is legal on prescription in the UK but banned in Egypt.

Plummer claimed the painkiller was to treat her Mr Caboo's back pain and has previously said she had "no idea" the tablets were illegal.

Laura Plummer said the prescription pills were for her partner Omar Caboo

Plummer's sister Rachel said their mother Roberta Synclair had been told her daughter would be held in police cells so she could visit her.

But the family said Ms Synclair went to the cells only to find that Plummer had already been transferred to a prison in Qena.

"Obviously that's even more devastating for my mum because she's not got to say goodbye to Laura," Rachel Plummer said.

"No prisons are nice but I think Qena's the bad one."

Plummer's lawyer Mohamed Othman told the BBC he was applying for her to be moved to Qanater prison, which is closer to Cairo, and has "better conditions" ahead of an appeal against her conviction.

原始正确信息:
Canadian Donna Penner was relaxed at the prospect of abdominal surgery - until she woke up just before the surgeon made his first incision. She describes how she survived the excruciating pain of being operated on while awake.

In 2008, I was booked in for an exploratory laparoscopy at a hospital in my home province of Manitoba in Canada. I was 44 and I had been experiencing heavy bleeding during my periods.

I'd had a general anaesthetic before and I knew I was supposed to have one for this procedure. I'd never had a problem with them, but when we got to the hospital I found myself feeling quite anxious.

During a laparoscopy, the surgeon makes incisions into your abdomen through which they will push instruments so they can take a look around. You have three or four small incisions instead of one big one.

The operation started off well. They moved me on to the operating table and started to do all the normal things that they do - hooking me up to all the monitors and prepping me.

The anaesthesiologist gave me something in an intravenous drip and then he put a mask on my face and said, "Take a deep breath." So I did, and drifted off to sleep like I was supposed to.

When I woke up I could still hear the sounds in the operating room. I could hear the staff banging and clanging and the machines going - the monitors and that kind of thing. I thought, "Oh good, it's over, it's done."

I was lying there feeling a little medicated, but at the same time I was also alert and enjoying that lazy feeling of waking up and feeling completely relaxed.

That changed a few seconds later when I heard the surgeon speak.

They were moving around and doing their things and then all of a sudden I heard him say, "Scalpel please." I just froze. I thought, "What did I just hear?"

There was nothing I could do. I had been given a paralytic, which is a common thing they do when work on the abdomen because it relaxes the abdominal muscles so they don't resist as much when you're cutting through them.

Unfortunately the general anaesthetic hadn't worked, but the paralytic had.

I panicked. I thought this cannot be happening. So I waited for a few seconds, but then I felt him make the first incision. I don't have words to describe the pain - it was horrific.

I could not open my eyes. The first thing that I tried to do was to sit up, but I couldn't move. It felt like somebody was sitting on me, weighing me down.
